alerts.name: CSP: Wildcard Directive
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

instances.evidence: default-src 'self';base-uri 'self';font-src 'self' https: data: https://client.crisp.chat/static/;form-action 'self';frame-ancestors 'self';img-src 'self' data: https://*.crisp.chat/;object-src 'none';script-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline' https://client.crisp.chat/;script-src-attr 'none';connect-src 'self' https://api-adresse.data.gouv.fr/ wss://client.relay.crisp.chat/ https://client.crisp.chat/static/ https://storage.crisp.chat/users/upload/ https://sentry.incubateur.net/;style-src 'self' https: 'unsafe-inline' https://client.crisp.chat/;upgrade-insecure-requests
instances.otherinfo:
The following directives either allow wildcard sources (or ancestors), are not defined, or are overly broadly defined:
style-src, font-src

alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is properly configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.otherinfo:
The following directives either allow wildcard sources (or ancestors), are not defined, or are overly broadly defined:

style-src, font-src

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Permissions-Policy header.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

instances.otherinfo: No links have been found while there are scripts, which is an indication that this is a modern web application.

alerts.solution: This is an informational alert and so no changes are required.
alerts.otherinfo: No links have been found while there are scripts, which is an indication that this is a modern web application.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.
alerts.solution: For secure content, ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate". If an asset should be cached consider setting the directives "public, max-age, immutable".

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Dest header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Mode header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Site header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-User header is included in user initiated requests.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

instances.otherinfo: In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.
In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.
In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.

alerts.solution:
Validate that the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information. If it does, consider the use of the following HTTP response headers, to limit, or prevent the content being stored and retrieved from the cache by another user:

Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private

Pragma: no-cache

Expires: 0

This configuration directs both HTTP 1.0 and HTTP 1.1 compliant caching servers to not store the response, and to not retrieve the response (without validation) from the cache, in response to a similar request.
